sen.j: 護国神社（ごこくじんじゃ）は、日本の各県に建立されている、その県出身の戦死者・自衛隊殉職者などを、日本国に殉じた英霊として祀る神社。
sen.e: Located in each prefecture in Japan, Gokoku-jinja Shrine is a shrine honoring the spirits of the fallen heroes who sacrificed themselves for Japan, including the war dead and victims to the Japan Self-Defense Forces from each prefecture.

Located in each prefecture in Japan, Gokoku-jinja Shrine is a shrine honoring the spirits of the fallen heroes who sacrificed themselves for Japan, including the war dead and victims to the Japan Self-Defense Forces from each prefecture.

Located in each prefecture in Japan, Gokoku-jinja Shrine is a shrine honoring the spirits of the fallen heroes who sacrificed themselves for Japan, including the war dead and victims to the Japan Self-Defense Forces from each prefecture.

sen.j: 概説
sen.e: Summary
Summary
Summary

sen.j: 明治時代に日本各地に設立された招魂社が、1939年（昭和14年）の内務省 (日本)によって一斉に改称したものである。
sen.e: Shokonsha, which was built around the country during the Meiji period, changed its name to Gokoku-jinja Shrine simultaneously by the ordinance of Ministry of Home Affairs (Japan) in 1939.
Shokonsha, which were built around the country during the Meiji period, had a name change to Gokoku-jinja Shrine simultaneously by an ordinance from the Ministry of Home Affairs (Japan) in 1939.
Shokonsha, which were built around the country during the Meiji period, had a name change to Gokoku-jinja Shrine simultaneously by an ordinance from the Ministry of Home Affairs (Japan) in 1939.

sen.j: おおむね各府県につき1社を府県社に相当する内務大臣指定護国神社（指定護国神社）とし、それ以外を村社に相当する指定外護国神社とした。
sen.e: Generally one Gokoku-jinja Shrine in each prefecture was categorized as a Home Minister-designated Gokoku-jinja Shrine, which corresponds to Fukensha (prefectural shrines), and other Gokoku-jinja Shrine was categorized as a non-designated Gokoku-jinja Shrine, which corresponds to sonsha (a village shrine).

Generally one Gokoku-jinja Shrine in each prefecture was categorized as a Home Minister-designated Gokoku-jinja Shrine, which corresponds to Fukensha (prefectural shrines), and other Gokoku-jinja Shrines were categorized as non-designated Gokoku-jinja Shrines, which correspond to sonsha (a village shrine).

Generally one Gokoku-jinja Shrine in each prefecture was categorized as a Home Minister-designated Gokoku-jinja Shrine, which corresponds to Fukensha (prefectural shrines), and other Gokoku-jinja Shrines were categorized as non-designated Gokoku-jinja Shrines, which correspond to sonsha (a village shrine).

sen.j: 敗戦後、護国神社は軍国主義施設と見なされ、存続を図るために名称から「護国神社」の文字を外して地名などを元に改称を余儀なくされた。
sen.e: After the war, Gokoku-jinja Shrine was deemed to be militaristic institutions and thus was forced to change its name based on, e.g., the name of a place, deleting "Gokoku-jinja," to survive.
After the war, Gokoku-jinja Shrines were deemed to be militaristic institutions and thus were forced to change names based on, e.g., the name of the place, deleting "Gokoku-jinja," to survive.
After the war, Gokoku-jinja Shrines were deemed to be militaristic institutions and thus were forced to change names based on, e.g., the name of the place, deleting 'Gokoku-jinja,' to survive.

sen.j: サンフランシスコ平和条約を締結し、日本が独立を回復すると、元の社名に戻した。
sen.e: After the conclusion of the San Francisco Peace Treaty and Japan's recovery of its independency, the shrines changed their name to the original.
After the conclusion of the San Francisco Peace Treaty and Japan's recovery of its independency, the shrines changed their names back to the original.
After the conclusion of the San Francisco Peace Treaty and Japan's recovery of its independency, the shrines changed their names back to the original.

sen.j: 唯一、青森縣護国神社だけは改称せず「護国神社」を守り通した。
sen.e: Only Gokoku-jinja Shrine in Aoyama Prefecture did not change its name and remained "Gokoku-jinja Shrine."
Only the Gokoku-jinja Shrine in Aoyama Prefecture did not change its name and remained "Gokoku-jinja Shrine."
Only the Gokoku-jinja Shrine in Aomori Prefecture did not change its name and remained 'Gokoku-jinja Shrine.'

sen.j: 戦後、いくつかの指定護国神社は神社本庁の別表神社となった。
sen.e: After the war, some of the designated Gokoku-jinja Shrines became the Association of Shinto Shrines' Beppyo-jinja Shrines listed on the exceptional list.
After the war, some of the designated Gokoku-jinja Shrines became the Association of Shinto Shrines' Beppyo-jinja Shrines listed on the exceptional list.
After the war, some of the designated Gokoku-jinja Shrines became the Association of Shinto Shrines' Beppyo-jinja Shrines listed on the exceptional list.

sen.j: 「招魂社」の「招魂」は臨時の、一時的な祭祀であるが、「社」は恒久施設である。
sen.e: "Shokon"(招魂) of "Shokonsha"(招魂社) means a provisional or temporary religious service, while "sha"(社) means a permanent institution.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "Shokon"(招魂) of "Shokonsha"(招魂社) means a provisional or temporary religious service, while "sha"(社) means a permanent institution.
Shokon' (招魂) of 'Shokonsha' (招魂社) means a provisional or temporary religious service, while 'sha' (社) means a permanent institution.

sen.j: 名称に矛盾があるために改称された。
sen.e: Due to the inconsistency, it was renamed.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Due to the inconsistency, it was renamed.
Due to the inconsistency, it was renamed.

sen.j: 指定護国神社は、北海道は3社、兵庫県・広島県・島根県・岐阜県では2社というように、一都道府県内に複数存在するところもある。
sen.e: The designated Gokoku-jinja Shrines exist more than one in some prefectures: three in Hokkaido and two in Hyogo, Hiroshima, Shimane, Gifu Prefectures, individually.
More than one designated Gokoku-jinja Shrines exist in some prefectures: three in Hokkaido and two in Hyogo, Hiroshima, Shimane, Gifu Prefectures, individually.
More than one designated Gokoku-jinja Shrines exist in some prefectures: three in Hokkaido and two in Hyogo, Hiroshima, Shimane, Gifu Prefectures, individually.

sen.j: （岐阜県の飛騨護国神社は主要護国神社の1社ではあるが、指定外となっている。）
sen.e: (Hida Gokoku-jinja Shrine in Gifu Prefecture is one of the major Gokoku-jinja Shrines, but it is categorized as a non-designated Gokoku-jinja Shrine.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: (Hida Gokoku-jinja Shrine in Gifu Prefecture is one of the major Gokoku-jinja Shrines, but it is categorized as a non-designated Gokoku-jinja Shrine.)
(Hida Gokoku-jinja Shrine in Gifu Prefecture is one of the major Gokoku-jinja Shrines, but it is categorized as a non-designated Gokoku-jinja Shrine.)

sen.j: これはかつての令制国や地域意識が強く残っていた地域では同じ県出身者でも違う「国」や地域出身の戦没者を受け入れない例があり、それが尾を引いているからだと言われている（例えば広島県の場合、かつての備後国と安芸国にそれぞれ1社存在する）。
sen.e: Some regions enduring the old consciousness of province and region did not accept the war dead from other "province" or region even if he was from the same prefecture, which supposedly remains as the reason for this (for example, Hiroshima Prefecture has two Gokoku-jinja Shrines: one in the former Bingo Province and the other in the former Aki Province).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Some regions enduring the old consciousness of province and region did not accept the war dead from other "provinces" or regions even if he was from the same prefecture, which supposedly remains as the reason for this (for example, Hiroshima Prefecture has two Gokoku-jinja Shrines: one in the former Bingo Province and the other in the former Aki Province).

Some regions enduring the old consciousness of province and region did not accept the war dead from other 'provinces' or regions even if he was from the same prefecture, which supposedly remains as the reason for this (for example, Hiroshima Prefecture has two Gokoku-jinja Shrines: one in the former Bingo Province and the other in the former Aki Province).

sen.j: 建設中に戦災で焼失した神奈川県（戦後、横浜市戦没者慰霊塔が建てられた）や、東京都（戦前より東京都慰霊堂があり、仏式で祭祀が行われる）と、存在しない都県もある。
sen.e: Some prefectures do not have Gokoku-jinja Shrine; one in Kanagawa Prefecture being destroyed by fire during the war while being constructed (Yokoyama City War Memorial Tower was built after the war) and one in Tokyo (Tokyo Memorial Hall was built before the war, where the religious service is held according to Buddhist rites).

Some prefectures do not have a Gokoku-jinja Shrine; Kanagawa Prefecture's being destroyed by fire during the war while being constructed (Yokoyama City War Memorial Tower was built after the war) and Tokyo (Tokyo Memorial Hall was built before the war, where the religious service is held according to Buddhist rites).

Some prefectures do not have a Gokoku-jinja Shrine; Kanagawa Prefecture's being destroyed by fire during the war while being constructed (Yokoyama City War Memorial Tower was built after the war) and Tokyo (Tokyo Memorial Hall was built before the war, where the religious service is held according to Buddhist rites).

sen.j: （東京都には別途靖國神社が存在する。）
sen.e: (Tokyo has Yasukuni-jinja Shrine specially.)
(Tokyo has Yasukuni-jinja Shrine specially.)
(Tokyo has Yasukuni-jinja Shrine specially.)

sen.j: 護国神社の祭神は分祀されたのではなく、独自で招魂し祭祀を執り行っているため、公式には「靖國神社とは本社分社の関係にはない」とされている。
sen.e: It is not that the enshrined deity of Gokoku-jinja Shrine was separated; it is officially said "Gokoku-jinja Shrine is not the branch shrine of Yasukuni-jinja Shrine" since it honors the spirits and holds religious services on its own accord.

It is not that the enshrined deity of Gokoku-jinja Shrine was separated; it is officially said "Gokoku-jinja Shrine is not a branch shrine of the Yasukuni-jinja Shrine" since it honors spirits and holds religious services on its own accord.

It is not that the enshrined deity of Gokoku-jinja Shrine was separated; it is officially said 'Gokoku-jinja Shrine is not a branch shrine of the Yasukuni-jinja Shrine' since it honors spirits and holds religious services on its own accord.

sen.j: しかし、共に英霊を祀る靖國神社と護国神社とは深い関わりを持ち交流がある。
sen.e: However, both Yasukuni-jinja Shrine and Gokoku-jinja Shrine honor the spirits of the fallen heroes and have a strong connection and exchanges.
However, both Yasukuni-jinja Shrine and Gokoku-jinja Shrine honor the spirits of the fallen heroes and have a strong connection and exchanges.
However, both Yasukuni-jinja Shrine and Gokoku-jinja Shrine honor the spirits of the fallen heroes and have a strong connection and exchanges.

sen.j: 主要な護国神社52社で組織する全國護國神社會（旧浦安会）は靖國神社と連携し、英霊顕彰の為の様々な活動を行っている。
sen.e: The National Association of Gokoku-jinja Shrines (the former Urawakai) comprising 52 major Gokoku-jinja Shrines cooperates with Yasukuni-jinja Shrine to do various activities such as honoring the spirits of the fallen heroes.

The National Association of Gokoku-jinja Shrines (the former Urawakai) comprising of 52 major Gokoku-jinja Shrines cooperates with Yasukuni-jinja Shrine to do various activities such as honoring the spirits of the fallen heroes.

The National Association of Gokoku-jinja Shrines (the former Urayasukai) comprising of 52 major Gokoku-jinja Shrines cooperates with Yasukuni-jinja Shrine to do various activities such as honoring the spirits of the fallen heroes.

sen.j: 1960年（昭和35年）、全国の護国神社52社に対して天皇・皇后より幣帛が下賜されて以降、終戦から数えて10年毎に幣帛の下賜が続けられている。
sen.e: In 1960, 52 Gokoku-jinja Shrines in the country were awarded heihaku (paper or silk cuttings or red and white cloth are presented to the gods) from the Emperor and Empress, thereafter this custom has continued for ten years annually since the end of the war.

In 1960, 52 Gokoku-jinja Shrines in the country were awarded heihaku (paper or silk cuttings or red and white cloth are presented to the gods) from the Emperor and Empress, thereafter this custom has continued for ten years annually since the end of the war.

In 1960, 52 Gokoku-jinja Shrines in the country were awarded heihaku (paper or silk cuttings or red and white cloth are presented to the gods) from the Emperor and Empress, thereafter this custom has continued for ten years annually since the end of the war.

sen.j: 靖國神社も護国神社と同様に、戦死者を英霊として祀る神社であり、やはり招魂社を改称したものである。
sen.e: Like Gokoku-jinja Shrine, Yasukuni-jinja Shrine is a shrine honoring the spirits of the war dead and was originated from Shokonsha.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Like Gokoku-jinja Shrines, Yasukuni-jinja Shrine is a shrine honoring the spirits of the war dead and originated from Shokonsha.
Like Gokoku-jinja Shrines, Yasukuni-jinja Shrine is a shrine honoring the spirits of the war dead and originated from Shokonsha.

sen.j: しかし、太平洋戦争当時まで日本人とされていた朝鮮民族、台湾人を含め日本全国どこの出身であっても祀られる対象となる点が異なっている。
sen.e: However, it differs from Gokoku-jinja Shrine in that it enshrines individuals from any region in Japan, including Koreans and Taiwanese who were identified as Japanese before the Pacific War.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, it differs from Gokoku-jinja Shrines in that it enshrines individuals from any region in Japan, including Koreans and Taiwanese who were identified as Japanese before the Pacific War.
However, it differs from Gokoku-jinja Shrines in that it enshrines individuals from any region in Japan, including Koreans and Taiwanese who were identified as Japanese before the Pacific War.

sen.j: これまで各地の護国神社を支えてきたのは戦没者の遺族会や戦友会であったが、高齢化とともにその数が激減している。
sen.e: So far, Gokoku-jinja Shrines in the country have been supported mainly by the war-bereaved association and veterans association, but the members of the associations are decreasing due to aging.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: So far, Gokoku-jinja Shrines in the country have been supported mainly by the war-bereaved association and veterans association, but the members of the associations are decreasing due to aging.
So far, Gokoku-jinja Shrines in the country have been supported mainly by the war-bereaved association and veterans association, but the members of the associations are decreasing due to aging.

sen.j: 財政的危機に見舞われる社が増えるのではないかと見られている。
sen.e: It is thus assumed that the increasing number of shrines will face a financial crisis.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is thus assumed that an increasing number of shrines will face financial crisis.
It is thus assumed that an increasing number of shrines will face financial crisis.

sen.j: 論争
sen.e: Controversy
Controversy
Controversy

sen.j: 戦後、軍人にかわり殉職した自衛官も護国神社に祀られるようになり、合祀申請は自衛隊の地方連絡部と社団法人隊友会により行われるようになった。
sen.e: After the war, Gokoku-jinja Shrine came to enshrine also self-defense officials who died on duty, replacing military men, and the application for collective enshrinement came to be handled by the Provincial Liaison Office of the Self Defense Forces and Taiyukai.

After the war, Gokoku-jinja Shrine came to also enshrine self-defense officials who died on duty, replacing military men, and the application for collective enshrinement came to be handled by the Provincial Liaison Office of the Self Defense Forces and Taiyukai.

After the war, Gokoku-jinja Shrine came to also enshrine self-defense officials who died on duty, replacing military men, and the application for collective enshrinement came to be handled by the Provincial Liaison Office of the Self Defense Forces and Taiyukai.

sen.j: が、戦前と同様合祀・合祀申請ともに遺族の同意を一切求めず行われるため、クリスチャンである殉職自衛官の妻が（他の遺族は全員賛成）、宗教的人格権を侵害されたとして損害賠償等を請求する事態に発展したことがある。
sen.e: However, since the collective enshrinement and its application proceeded without an agreement with the bereaved family like in the prewar period, the situation once developed that a Christian wife of the self-defense official who died on duty (other family members all agreed with the collective enshrinement) asked for compensation or the like for religious human rights violations.

However, since the collective enshrinement and its application proceeded without an agreement with the bereaved family like in the prewar period, a situation once developed where the Christian wife of a self-defense official who died on duty (other family members all agreed with the collective enshrinement) asked for compensation or the like for religious human rights violations.

However, since the collective enshrinement and its application proceeded without an agreement with the bereaved family like in the prewar period, a situation once developed where the Christian wife of a self-defense official who died on duty (other family members all agreed with the collective enshrinement) asked for compensation or the like for religious human rights violations.

sen.j: （自衛官護国神社合祀事件・最大昭和57(オ)902号事件/判昭和63年6月1日/判例集第42巻5号277頁）
sen.e: (Self-defense official Gokoku-jinja Shrine collective enshrinement case; Case No. Max. Showa 57(オ)902/Decided June 1, 1988/Digest, Vol. 42, No. 5, p. 277.)
(Self-defense official Gokoku-jinja Shrine collective enshrinement case; Case No. Max. Showa 57(オ)902/Decided June 1, 1988/Digest, Vol. 42, No. 5, p. 277.)
(Self-defense official Gokoku-jinja Shrine collective enshrinement case; Case No. Max. Showa 57(O)902/Decided June 1, 1988/Digest, Vol. 42, No. 5, p. 277.)

sen.j: 現在、護国神社はどちらかと言えば各地でひっそりと地味に存在している神社であり、靖國神社程には人々の関心が向けられることや政治論争に巻き込まれることが比較的少ない。
sen.e: Currently, Gokoku-jinja Shrine is a shrine standing rather quietly and locally, in which people are less interested than in Yasukuni-jinja Shrine and which is not often involved in political contention.

Currently, Gokoku-jinja Shrines are shrines standing rather quietly and locally, in which people are less interested in than Yasukuni-jinja Shrine and which are not often involved in political contention.

Currently, Gokoku-jinja Shrines are shrines standing rather quietly and locally, in which people are less interested in than Yasukuni-jinja Shrine and which are not often involved in political contention.

sen.j: これには英霊顕彰に関する関心が靖國神社ばかりに集中していることを嘆く声もある反面、祀られている祭神にとって静かで平穏な環境を保つことができていると肯定的な意見もある。
sen.e: Some people complain that the public has an intense interest in Yasukuni-jinja Shrine regarding honoring the spirits of the fallen heroes, while others positively think that Gokoku-jinja Shrine can therefore retain a peace and quiet environment for the enshrined deity.

Some people complain that the public has an intense interest in Yasukuni-jinja Shrine regarding honoring the spirits of the fallen heroes, while others positively think that Gokoku-jinja Shrines can therefore retain a peaceful and quiet environment for the enshrined deity.

Some people complain that the public has an intense interest in Yasukuni-jinja Shrine regarding honoring the spirits of the fallen heroes, while others positively think that Gokoku-jinja Shrines can therefore retain a peaceful and quiet environment for the enshrined deity.

sen.j: 「指定」は内務大臣指定護国神社、「別表」は神社本庁別表神社。
sen.e: "Designated" indicates the Home Minister-designated Gokoku-jinja Shrines and "Exceptional list" indicates the Association of Shinto Shrines' Beppyo-jinja Shrines listed on the exceptional list.
"Designated" indicates the Home Minister-designated Gokoku-jinja Shrines and "Exceptional list" indicates the Association of Shinto Shrines' Beppyo-jinja Shrines listed on the exceptional list.
